docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 U.S. Reshapes Alliances After War With Iraq The Bush administration's recent moves to reshape alliances with leaders from Japan, Australia and the Philippines are part of its intense effort to compensate for the breaches with its traditional allies that became so visible during the war in Iraq. A1 Iran's Moves Called Insufficient White House officials said the Iranian government's arrests of members of Al Qaeda operating in its territory had failed to ease American concerns about Iran's support for terrorist activities. A14

docs.lead_paragraph: Arguing that legal costs and big jury awards are overwhelming them, insurance companies and other businesses have stepped up efforts in the states to restrict medical malpractice lawsuits and other kinds of personal injury suits. Bills are now pending in more than 20 states, and lawmakers have approved measures in at least 11 more states this year, as tracked by proponents of the lawsuit restrictions. The bills aim to limit awards for pain and suffering, reduce the amount of money that defendants must pay to appeal a decision and apportion liability for damages based on a defendant's share of any blame.

headline.main: Pressure Increases For Tighter Limits On Injury Lawsuits

docs.abstract: Insurers and other companies step up efforts to get states to restrict medical malpractice lawsuits and other kinds of personal injury suits, arguing that legal costs and big jury awards are overwhelming them; bills are pending in more than twenty states, with measures approved in 11; map; intense lobbying also continues in Congress for broad litigation relief; trial lawyers organize advertising counterattacks in New York, Pennsylvania and Florida (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In response to intense pressure from investors, Jeffrey C. Barbakow stepped down yesterday as chief executive of Tenet Healthcare, the troubled hospital chain. Mr. Barbakow, an investment banker brought in 10 years ago to run Tenet, will remain chairman until Tenet's annual shareholder meeting in July, the company said. Trevor Fetter, Tenet's president, was named acting chief executive. Mr. Fetter, who left in 2000 to run a spinoff of the company, was brought back in November as part of a management overhaul to address increasing concerns.

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; With No Surprise, Chief Is Out at Tenet Healthcare

docs.abstract: Tenet Healthcare chief executive Jeffrey C Barbakow, in response to intense pressure from investors, resigns; will remain chairman untile Tenet's annual shareholder meeting in July; president Trevor Fetter is named acting chief executive; regulators are looking into Tenet's aggressive pricing policy and its charges to Medicare; Tenet has since changed policy; concerns about its quality of care developed after FBI raided Tenet hospital for information about accusations of unnecessary procedures by two doctors; photo (Market Place column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Cases column ''Treating Symptoms and Missing Disease'' (May 20) rings especially true for psychiatry, where human behavioral variation gets caught in ever-broadening diagnostic nets and divvied up into symptom categories. Anxious/hypervigilant types, today deemed pathologic, were once great sentinels in a world of saber-toothed cats and competing tribes.
docs.abstract: Dr Christopher Bailey letter on how May 20 article on doctors treating symptoms but missing disease applies to psychiatry (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cities around Connecticut are holding their breath as they wait nervously to find out how much the state's severe budget crunch will cost them. But here inside the gilded enclaves of Fairfield County, mayors and first selectmen are putting the finishing touches on spending plans that are only mildly different from years past. They never got much help from the state because of their affluent citizenry and super-size grand lists of taxable property, so now they are experiencing less pain than other cities. ''The wealthier suburban communities are less reliant on state funds,'' said Westport's first selectwoman, Diane Farrell. Her town got only 1 percent of its budget from the state in good times, so the $107,000 or so she expects to lose next year is the least of her worries. ''Obviously, every loss is lamentable,'' she said. ''But the money is not significant enough to throw us into a budgetary tailspin.''

headline.main: Times Only a Little Tough in Fairfield County

docs.abstract: Some Connecticut cities wait nervously to find out how much state's severe budget crunch will cost them, but not those in Fairfield County, which never got much help from state because of their affluent citizenry and super-size grand lists of taxable property; spending plans in Greenwich, New Canaan, Westport and Stamford noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE a lot of alcoholics in management positions, Brian Early was able to get the job done, he says, despite all the drinking he did at lunch and the barhopping he did after work. ''People used to say, 'Brian's a hard charger,' and 'Brian drinks a lot,' but they didn't know the extent of it,'' Mr. Early, 45, said of his earlier days as national accounts manager at Wagers, a dealer for Toshiba office products in St. Paul 22 years ago. ''I was getting up the next morning and smoking dope just to get rid of the headache.''

headline.main: Executive Life; Detoured, but Not Stopped, by Alcohol

docs.abstract: Executives with drinking problems often tell themselves that they cannot be out of control because they can handle their demanding positions; have easier time than other people hiding their drinking; tend to seek treatment later than others but have higher rates of recovery; Brian Early, executive who had his last drink 22 years ago, comments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR much of the last month, the people responsible for the health of the sputtering economy have been performing a series of emergency procedures. With the economy showing new signs of weakness, the House and Senate overcame sharp differences last week to pass a $320 billion tax cut intended in part to increase stock prices and give households additional money to spend. Alan Greenspan has been assuring investors that the Federal Reserve will act aggressively to prevent deflation, an unlikely but dangerous possibility.

headline.main: The World: Long Haul; A Sickly Economy, With No Cure in Sight

docs.abstract: Tax cut and other governmental steps to help spluttering economy discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This is a story about fighting Palestinian chaos and corruption, about seeking to throw off Israeli occupation and build a democratic state of Palestine. It is about these things, because it is about one man's lonely pursuit of direct deposit. The man is Salam Fayyad, the Palestinian minister of finance, the kind of Palestinian you rarely hear about, an economist trained in Texas who has never fired a gun, sent men into battle or served time in prison or exile. He met recently in Gaza City with half a dozen men who had done these things -- who do some of them still -- the chiefs of Yasir Arafat's Gaza security services, the most hardened of Palestinian warriors. It was Fayyad's intention to intimidate them.
docs.abstract: James Bennet profile of Salam Fayyad, Palestinian Authority's minister of finance; Fayyad is economist who is trying to eliminate corruption from system run on cash that pays for security, but perhaps also finances violence that security agencies are supposed to prevent; is crusader for clean government and may have designs on position of prime minister but is outsider to Palestinian political establishment; personal and career highlights noted; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the midst of the slickest spring rainstorms students at Murray Avenue School here can go rock climbing. Last fall, the elementary school's PTA paid $5,000 to install a climbing wall in the school gymnasium. Since then, students as young as 5 have traversed the 8 1/2-foot-high, 32-foot-wide wall, developing upper body strength, agility and balance along the way, said the school's physical education teachers, Craig Butler and Kathleen Dwyer.

headline.main: Up a Wall, Slowly, Or Fast at School

docs.abstract: Article on rock climbing wall installed in gym at Murray Avenue elementary school in Larchmont, NY, with funds from school's PTA; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After two months of intense secret negotiations, governors and Bush administration officials have been unable to agree on a plan to rein in the soaring cost of Medicaid, participants in the talks say. Governors of both parties are resisting a proposal offered by President Bush this year to set firm limits on federal Medicaid spending in each state over the next decade.

headline.main: GOVERNORS RESIST BUSH PLAN TO SLOW COSTS OF MEDICAID

docs.abstract: Governors and Bush administration fail in two months of intense secret negotiations to agree on plan to rein in soaring cost of Medicaid; governors are resisting proposal offered by Pres Bush this year to set firm limits on federal Medicaid spending in each state over next decade, fearing that it does not protect states against unforeseen costs that might result from changes in economy, natural disasters, outbreaks of disease or development of expensive drugs and other treatments; resistance comes not just from Democrats, since Republicans like Jeb Bush of Florida and John G Rowland of Connecticut are also expressing reservations; graphs; photo (M)
